controller

Class Interpreter

  • java.lang.Object
    • controller.Interpreter

  • public class Interpreter
extends Object
    This is the controller class. It is a singleton. Do not use the constructor. Use the getInstance() method instead which gives you the instance of the class. It translates Prolog-like declaration into objects for the program.
    Author:
    Albex

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private static Interpreter instance

      • instance

        private static volatile Interpreter instance

    • Constructor Detail

      • Interpreter

        private Interpreter()
        Constructor of the class. To be not used by itself as the class is a singleton. Use the specific method getInstance instead.
        See Also:
        getInstance()

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static final Interpreter getInstance()
        Gets the only object of this singleton class. Use it as a static method.
        Returns:
        instance the only object of this class. If the object was not already created it will create it.

      • isProlog

        public boolean isProlog(String string)
        Checks if the input string is in the form of a Prolog predicate. This string should have the form of 'someLettersOrNumbersOr_(aValue,anotherValue,AVariable,AnotherVariable)'. See a Prolog documentation for more information about Prolog predicate. This method is used to throw exceptions in prologToPredicate.
        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether it is a Prolog predicate or not.
        Returns:
        true if it matches the general form of a Prolog predicate, otherwise false.

      • prologToPredicate

        public Predicate prologToPredicate(String string)
                            throws RemoteException
        Creates the Predicate object corresponding to the input string containing the Prolog declaration of the predicate.
        Parameters:
        string - the Prolog version of the predicate to be saved.
        Returns:
        a Predicate object. Then it will need to be stored in some place of the LPS framework.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the string is not a Prolog predicate according to the isProlog method.

      • isDPostDeclaration

        public boolean isDPostDeclaration(String string)
        Checks whether the input string is a Prolog-like DPost declaration or not. You might need to have a look at an LPS documentation. This method is used to throw exceptions in prologToDPost.
        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it matches the Prolog-like syntax.
        Returns:
        true if the string is a DPost declaration, otherwise false.

      • prologToDPost

        public DPostDeclaration prologToDPost(String string)
                               throws RemoteException
        Creates a DPostDeclaration object of the input string which should be written as a Prolog-like DPost declaration.
        Parameters:
        string - the Prolog-like syntax of the DPost declaration.
        Returns:
        a DPostDeclaration object which will be either a Initiator object or a Terminator object. It depends on the nature of the DPost declaration, whether it is an 'initiates' or 'a 'terminates'.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the string is not a DPost declaration according to the method isDPostDeclaration.
